bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 19, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his devotion to Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 19, 1875

opener.dateline:
Blacks & Whites,
Nottoway Co;, Va.
May 19th, 1875.

div1.p:
I believe that I
told you, in my letter written from
Norfolk, that I would come to this
place instead of going on to Church-
land. I arrived, yesterday after-
noon, & gave them all a genuine
surprise- Of course, they did not ex-
pect me so soon & my sudden ap-
pearance threw them into a mingled state
of confusion and happiness- Still,
they were not quite so much
confused as you were just one
week ago; nor did they hesitate to
meet me, as you did. Bless your
sweet heart, I appreciate your
feelings on that occassion, & if you
experienced a little nervousness, it
will not surprise you to be told
that my breast was not altogether
placid. How could it be, when every
moment was hurrying me face to
face withto the one woman that I loved?

lg.l: 'Tis easy act to grasp the quill,
When all the world is calm & still,
But ah! to look in love's pure eye,

div1.p:
Nothing but the consciousness
of sincerity & truth enabled me to
meet you, but possessing these, I did
not hesitate to do so. Ah! I thank Heaven
that I did not go with a gilded sto-
ry such as has won many a sim-
ple-minded girl's affection- A passion
felt to-day, but, to-morrow, gone- No!
No! mine was of another kind indeed,
but it needs no repetition here
to constrain your belief. I know that
you believe me, & 'tis this very knowl-
edge that makes me happy; that kin-
dles my aspirations, &that brightens
my future. Before I saw you last,
I was sad, indeed, but now that
I know that there is one who will re-
joice with me in my prosperity &
console me with me in adversity,
the cloud, which darkened my
way so long has broken away &
I behold a brighter, better day.
Perhaps, while reading this, the thought
has occurred to you that I may
not remain in this state of mind;
that the a flame which burns so
brightly will soon exhaust
itself & leave nothing but a
few ashes behind. But a flame does
not lose its brilliancy as long as
proper fuel is supplied; by which
I mean to say that as long as the
fuel of your love shall last, so
long will the blaze of my affection
continue to shine brightly. Do not
think that the p I even anticipate suchthe
a time when you will cease to love
me or I to love you, for I would
not thus think if I could.
I showed your photograph to my
sister (I believe it was the first thing
I did after my arrival,) & she, at once,
fell in love with it. I laughingly
told her that you had an idea (or rather
had had) that I was exacting & harsh, when
she exclaimed; “bless her darling
heart! could I see her one hour; she
would never thus think again.” I must
close my third letter-
div1.closer:
Trusting to hear
from you soon, I remain, affectionately
and devotedly yours, Walter.
